etymology.description: semantic: 鳥(鳥) (niǎo, "bird") + phonetic: 凰(凰) (huáng, "female phoenix") = majestic bird -> phoenix
etymology.interpretation: The character 鳳(鳳) (fèng, "phoenix") combines the bird radical 鳥(鳥) (niǎo, "bird") with the phonetic 凰(凰) (huáng, "female phoenix") to denote a mythical and majestic bird associated with auspiciousness.
etymology.simplification: 鳳(鳳) was simplified to 凤(鳳) with 又(又) (yòu, "again") serving as a cursive shorthand for the bird radical 鳥(鳥) (niǎo, "bird").

examples.chinese: 传说中有一只鳳(傳說中有一隻鳳)，浴火重生为祥瑞(浴火重生為祥瑞)。
examples.pinyin: Chuánshuō zhōng yǒu yī zhī fèng, yùhuǒ chóngshēng wéi xiángruì.
examples.english: According to legend, a phoenix is reborn from fire as an auspicious sign.

examples.chinese: 文人墨客常以鳳(文人墨客常以鳳)，象征永恒之美(象徵永恆之美)。
examples.pinyin: Wénrén mòkè cháng yǐ fèng, xiàngzhēng yǒnghéng zhī měi.
examples.english: Literati often use the phoenix to symbolize eternal beauty.

examples.chinese: 古籍记载鳳(古籍記載鳳)，与龙同现祥瑞(與龍同現祥瑞)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔjí jìzǎi fèng, yǔ lóng tóng xiàn xiángruì.
examples.english: Ancient texts record that the phoenix appears alongside the dragon as an omen of good fortune.
